description: From French spectre, from Latin spectrum (“appearance, apparition”). Doublet of spectrum.

entries.meaning: A ghostly apparition, a phantom. [from 17th c.]
examples: A specter haunted the cemetery at the old Vasquez manor.

A specter is haunting Europe — the specter of communism. All the powers of old Europe have entered into a holy alliance to exorcise this specter: Pope and Tsar, Metternich and Guizot, French Radicals and German police-spies.

entries.meaning: (entomology) Any of certain species of dragonfly of the genus Boyeria, family Aeshnidae. [from 20th c.]
